article.headline: Conlon needed for Huskies to put away Hawaii
article.linkText: Reserve's key 3-pointer sparks No. 4 UConn past Hawaii
article.story:
HONOLULU (AP) -- Connecticut's Diana Taurasi said reserve Maria
Conlon's key 3-pointer with 4:20 remaining Saturday was not
something she hadn't seen before.

	   ''She does that every day in practice,'' said Taurasi, who
scored 18 points to lead the Huskies (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today; No. 5 Associated Press) to a 60-53
victory Saturday over Hawaii in the second round of the Rainbow
Wahine Classic.

	   Conlon sank her shot after Hawaii closed to four points.

	   Ashley Battle had 13 points and eight rebounds for the Huskies
(4-0), who led by as many as 15 points in the second half.

	   April Atuaia paced Hawaii (3-1) with 17 points, and Christen
Roper had 12 points and 11 rebounds.

	   Connecticut's defense kept the ball out of the hands of Hawaii's
post players.

	   ''When we got it in, their guards came down and helped, trying
to double-team on our post players,'' Hawaii coach Vince Goo said.

	   UConn coach Geno Auriemma said that was the biggest factor in
the victory.

	   ''We felt their big kid (Roper) was really a big part of their
offense,'' Auriemma said. ''If we could get the ball out of her
hands, it would make it tougher for them.

	   ''Our big kids did a good job rotating down on defense, trying
to keep them off balance as much as we could.''

	   But as Connecticut tried to extend its lead, Hawaii countered
with free-throw shooting and 3-pointers by April Atuaia and
Michelle Gabriel to close the deficit late in the game.

	   ''Every time we tried to spread it out on them and get a little
bit of a lead, they miraculously appeared at the free-throw line,''
Auriemma said. ''We knew it was going to come down to the end.

	   ''We knew we had to make some shots because they weren't going
to give us anything inside.''

	   Hawaii made only 26 percent of its shots in the first half, and
trailed by 12 points at the break. But the Rainbow Wahine shot 41.7
percent in the second half.

	   Then Conlon ended Hawaii's hopes with her 3-pointer. Neither
team scored again until Taurasi sank two free throws with 34
seconds to go.
